stream_context.summary: Kaze works on a space/arcade-themed level, focusing on programming new gameplay objects (warp platforms, low-gravity zones), fixing visual bugs, and refining the aesthetic of platforms and effects. He also discusses the upcoming demo and a hypothetical plan to create an original IP version of the game.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is replacing significant portions of the original Super Mario 64 code not just for legal reasons, but because he finds it extremely inefficient and poorly written.
development_findings.quote: The code is complete dog ass... Why was there 50% inefficiency on 4 lines of code?

development_findings.summary: To resolve a visual bug with custom materials, Kaze disabled Mario's default transparency effect for warping and implemented a new custom animation where Mario's model scales into the ground.
development_findings.quote: I think actually my life would be easier if we disabled the ability of Mario to go transparent. Because the materials we have do not allow for it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze described his level design process: first, he programs all the necessary objects and mechanics for a level, then experiments with their placement to discover fun gameplay, and finally polishes the successful combinations.
The game is being actively developed and tested to run on original N64 hardware, with Kaze monitoring and accepting performance that sometimes dips below 30 FPS in visually dense areas.
development_findings.quote: Did you think this could run on the N64? ... It's only like when you're looking at like the whole level and drops below 30 sometimes.

development_findings.summary: The game's design philosophy is to offer more challenging platforming than the original SM64, balanced by providing the player with more reliable and consistent movement controls.
development_findings.quote: A lot of the platforming is more difficult. But the movement is so much more consistent. And it just works. So it kinda balances out.

development_findings.summary: A significant technical breakthrough was freeing up a full megabyte of RAM on the N64, creating substantial room for new features or optimizations.
development_findings.quote: Yeah, finding a full megabyte was definitely a nice surprise.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is implementing custom lighting effects, such as a platform that emits its own light source from below to illuminate Mario.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is seriously considering creating a parallel, commercially viable version of the game by replacing all Nintendo IP with original assets, allowing it to be sold on platforms like Steam.
context_findings.quote: What if, along with RTYI, I also release a game that is 90% the same content, but we replace all the Nintendo IP with our own? That is the idea.

context_findings.summary: Kaze dislikes the greeting "How are you?", viewing it as an insincere and intrusive social ritual that forces a dishonest response. He connects this feeling to his German cultural background.
context_findings.quote: It's a question where you're not allowed to say the wrong answer... there is like an inherent torture to the question.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is strategically delaying the game's demo release to avoid conflicting with another creator's launch, showing a sense of community etiquette.
context_findings.quote: I don't want to ruin his release.

context_findings.summary: He closely follows other indie N64-style Kickstarters, noting high backer pledge amounts as valuable data for potential future commercial projects.
Kaze holds a cynical view of the video game industry, believing the general quality is low, which lowers the barrier to making a standout game.
context_findings.quote: Video games are fucking awful, which means the competition is not very strong.

biobak.summary: The team's workflow involves Kaze creating placeholder art and textures, which Biobak, the main graphics artist, then reworks and finalizes.
biobak.quote: I probably shouldn't spend so much time on textures and stuff. Considering Biobak is reworking all my stuff anyway. I should just leave it to him.

zeina.summary: Zeina, an animator and Kaze's wife, contributed the 3D model for the arcade-style carpet in the level being developed.
zeina.quote: What do you think of this carpet that Zeina made? Pretty cool, eh?

zeina.summary: Zeina is an active participant in the stream chat, engaging with Kaze about the level's progress.

key_stories.title: The Original IP Pivot Strategy
key_stories.summary: Kaze grapples with the legal limitations of creating a ROM hack and devises a strategy to release a commercially viable version by swapping all Nintendo assets for original IP, altering gameplay, and selling it on Steam.
key_stories.challenge: The game is a ROM hack based on Nintendo IP, making it impossible to monetize or distribute legally on major platforms like Steam.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed a plan to create a parallel version of the game. This would involve replacing all Nintendo assets with original IP, altering the moveset to create a functionally different game, and using the decompilation project to port it to PC for a Steam release.
key_stories.outcome: The idea is a serious, albeit hypothetical, consideration for the future, representing a potential path to legitimizing and monetizing the project's extensive development work.
key_stories.key_quote: What if, along with RTYI, I also release a game that is 90% the same content, but we replace all the Nintendo IP with our own? That is the idea.

key_stories.title: Replacing the Warp Animation
key_stories.summary: When a vanilla visual effect (transparency) broke due to engine modifications, Kaze opted to replace it with a completely new, custom scaling animation, showing a pragmatic approach that prioritizes the stability of his new systems.
key_stories.challenge: Mario's default transparency effect, used for warping, was causing visual glitches because it conflicted with the game's new custom materials and shaders.
key_stories.process: Kaze identified that fixing the transparency was too complex and would interfere with other systems. He decided to disable the feature entirely and instead created a new warp effect where Mario's model scales down into the ground.
key_stories.outcome: The new scaling animation provided a visually clean warp effect that was technically simpler and avoided conflicts with the rendering engine, becoming the new standard for the game.
key_stories.key_quote: I think that is the correct thing. We also don't use Mario's transparency, so there's no point to it.

key_stories.title: The Philosophy of a Greeting
key_stories.summary: In a tangent, Kaze explains his deep-seated aversion to the greeting "How are you?", deconstructing it as an insincere social ritual. This provides a significant insight into his personality, cultural background, and preference for direct communication.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze was prompted by his chat to explain his dislike for the common greeting "How are you?".
key_stories.process: He deconstructed the question, explaining that he perceives it as an intrusive interrogation that forces a socially acceptable but often dishonest answer. He described the awkwardness of answering truthfully and called the interaction an "inherent torture," connecting it to his German background.
key_stories.outcome: The monologue revealed a core aspect of Kaze's personality: a preference for directness, a disdain for what he perceives as insincere social rituals, and an analytical way of thinking about everyday interactions.
key_stories.key_quote: Imagine someone asks you, hello, how are you? And you answer, good, which phone do you have? Just as like a blanket response. Just like, that's how I feel.
